Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Integrated Geotechnical and Geophysical Investigation of Subaqueous Foundations, Levees and River Banks Impacted by Hurricane Harvey

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Harvey caused severe wind damages and flooding in Fall, 2017. In fact, the associated flooding can be classified as a 5,000 year event. Associated to the flooding, significant sediment relocation processes occurred. Sediment erosion around submerged structures and foundations, commonly referred to as scour, represents a significant risk to the stability of infrastructures. During Hurricane Harvey, early reconnaissance teams observed significant scour and erosion at bridge piers, river embankments, sheet pile walls, boulder walls, and other infrastructure with submerged foundations. However, safety constraints limited on site investigations while water levels were still elevated. An issue of post-event scour and erosion investigations is the refilling of scour holes. This means that when with receding water levels and flow velocities, sediment transported in suspensions settles and infills the scour holes, often leading to false assessments of the magnitude of erosion during the event. Additionally, the infill is freshly deposited and often weak, potentially providing a false image of stability. This award will support the collection of perishable field data investigating scour and erosion, as well as post-event infill at locations impacted by flooding and storm surge during Hurricane Harvey. The collected data will advance the understanding of scour, erosion, and infill during extreme flooding events, and therefore, contribute directly to the improvement of risk assessment.

The research team will visit sites that experienced severe scour and erosion during Hurricane Harvey, and that were initially investigated by early reconnaissance teams. An integrated geotechnical and geophysical approach will be employed to gather a unique data set of scour and erosion, and the subsequent infilling. Sub-bottom echo sounders (chirp sonar) will profile the submerged sediment stratigraphy, supported by portable free fall penetrometer deployments which will provide geotechnical parameters of the different sediment layers. Side scan sonar and photogrammetry will provide detailed imagery and topography. In-situ erodibility will be tested using a cohesive strength meter. Gravity coring will enable sediment sampling in submerged areas, while push tube sampling will be conducted at emerged banks. Sediment samples will be tested for geotechnical sediment characteristics, and erodibility. The latter tests will be conducted using a Erosion Flume Apparatus. The collected field data will be unique by providing geotechnical information from the native sediments and the infill, and will enable future research and insights into the erosion and infill processes associated to extreme flooding events as during Hurricane Harvey. The data will be made available to the public and other researchers immediately after collection through the Designsafe-CI data repository.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hurricane Harvey caused severe wind damages and flooding in Fall, 2017. In fact, the associated flooding can be classified as a 5,000 year event. Associated with the flooding, significant sediment relocation processes occurred. Sediment erosion around submerged structures and foundations, commonly referred to as scour, represents a significant risk to the stability of infrastructures. An issue of post-event scour and erosion investigations is the refilling of scour holes. This means that when with receding water levels and flow velocities, sediment transported in suspension settles and infills the scour holes, often leading to false assessments of the magnitude of erosion during the event. Additionally, the infill is freshly deposited and often weak, potentially providing a false image of stability. During this award, perishable field data investigating scour and erosion, as well as post-event infill at locations impacted by flooding and storm surge during Hurricane Harvey were collected. Sections of the Guadalupe, Colorado, and Brazos Rivers were visited, respectively. The river sections included different scenarios of river - infrastructure interactions: a bridge with abutments and multiple bridge supporting piles spanning the Guadalupe River in an area of significant river meandering; a bridge with abutments and multiple bridge supporting piles spanning the Colorado River where multiple severe river bank failures and damages to a local pump station occurred during Hurricane Harvey; a Brazos River section where multiple severe river bank slope failure occurred near a local subdivision community and electric infrastructure. Each of the river sections opposed multiple challenges to field data and sample collection such as access for only small support vessels (i.e., dinghy, canoe) that can be operated in shallow water and do not require a boat ramp, as well as unknown debris hidden within the rivers.

Geotechnical and geophysical field data were collected to assess river flow conditions, local geomorphology and changes in river bed elevation near infrastructure due to scour, and river bed and bank soil characteristics. Physical soil samples were collected at representative locations in all three river sections. Those samples were further analyzed for geotechnical soil characteristics in the geotechnical laboratories at Virginia Tech and Louisiana State University. The field and laboratory data have been used for the assessment of the field data collection methods and strategies in the context of the specific environmental conditions and restrictions, for the investigation of local sediment transport processes under extreme events, and for the development of numerical simulations of river bank stability.

The results contribute to advancing the understanding of scour, erosion, and infill during extreme flooding events, and therefore, to the improvement of risk assessment. The data is available to the public and other researchers through the Designsafe-CI data repository. A synthesis of the results was published at an international research conference and is in preparation for publication in a full peer-reviewed research journal. A second research journal contribution is expected to result from the numerical simulations. In addition to advancing our current understanding of impacts on river bed sediments from extreme flooding, the collected data and results of this award will enable future research and insights into the erosion and infill processes associated with extreme flooding events as during Hurricane Harvey. Finally, multiple graduate students from all three participating institutions were actively participating in this project, and by doing so, were trained in field, laboratory, and/or numerical methods and were mentored in data analysis, synthesis, and dissemination. A female graduate student is the lead author of two of the publications.
